rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.

Line 285: Line 285:
{{Further|[[ArabâIsraeli conflict]], [[IsraeliâPalestinian conflict]], and [[Positions on Jerusalem]]}}
{{Further|[[ArabâIsraeli conflict]], [[IsraeliâPalestinian conflict]], and [[Positions on Jerusalem]]}}
{{See also|List of United Nations resolutions concerning Israel}}
{{See also|List of United Nations resolutions concerning Israel}}
â
[[File:Soldiers Western Wall 1967.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] Paratroopers enter the [[Old City (Jerusalem)|Old City]] of [[Jerusalem]], June 7, 1967 ([[Six Day War]])]]
+
[[Arab nationalism|Arab nationalists]] led by Egyptian President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] refused to recognize Israel, calling for its destruction.<ref name=RoutledgeAtlas/><ref>{{Citation |title=Syria and Israel: From War to Peacemaking |last=Maoz |first=Moshe |authorlink= |year=1995 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=USA |isbn=978-0198280187 |page=70 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> By 1966, Israeli-Arab relations had deteriorated to the point of actual battles taking place between official Israeli and Arab forces.<ref>{{harvnb|Segev|2007|p=178}}</ref> In 1967, Egypt expelled [[United Nations Emergency Force|UN peacekeepers]], stationed in the Sinai Peninsula since 1957, and announced a partial blockade of Israel's access to the Red Sea.<ref>{{harvnb|Segev|2007|p=289}}</ref> Israel saw these actions as a ''[[casus belli]]'' for a [[preemptive war|pre-emptive strike]] that launched the [[Six-Day War]], in which Israel achieved a decisive victory and captured the West Bank, Gaza Strip, [[Sinai Peninsula]] and [[Golan Heights]].<ref>{{harvnb|Smith|2006|p=126}}. "Nasser, the Egyptian president, decided to mass troops in the Sinai...casus belli by Israel."</ref> Jerusalem's boundaries were enlarged, incorporating [[East Jerusalem]], and the 1949 [[Green Line (Israel)|Green Line]] became the administrative boundary between Israel and the [[Israeli-occupied territories|occupied territories]].
[[Arab nationalism|Arab nationalists]] led by Egyptian President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] refused to recognize Israel, calling for its destruction.<ref name=RoutledgeAtlas/><ref>{{Citation |title=Syria and Israel: From War to Peacemaking |last=Maoz |first=Moshe |authorlink= |year=1995 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=USA |isbn=978-0198280187 |page=70 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> By 1966, Israeli-Arab relations had deteriorated to the point of actual battles taking place between official Israeli and Arab forces.<ref>{{harvnb|Segev|2007|p=178}}</ref> In 1967, Egypt expelled [[United Nations Emergency Force|UN peacekeepers]], stationed in the Sinai Peninsula since 1957, and announced a partial blockade of Israel's access to the Red Sea.<ref>{{harvnb|Segev|2007|p=289}}</ref> Israel saw these actions as a ''[[casus belli]]'' for a [[preemptive war|pre-emptive strike]] that launched the [[Six-Day War]], in which Israel achieved a decisive victory and captured the West Bank, Gaza Strip, [[Sinai Peninsula]] and [[Golan Heights]].<ref>{{harvnb|Smith|2006|p=126}}. "Nasser, the Egyptian president, decided to mass troops in the Sinai...casus belli by Israel."</ref> Jerusalem's boundaries were enlarged, incorporating [[East Jerusalem]], and the 1949 [[Green Line (Israel)|Green Line]] became the administrative boundary between Israel and the [[Israeli-occupied territories|occupied territories]].
